tool.name: aggregator

param.name: inputSSURGO
param.dialogReference:
For the moment this optional parameter is for convenience in selecting a gSSURGO dataset from your map table of contents.

Eventually this parameter will be used to join the summary table to and map produced.

param.name: inputFolder
param.dialogReference: Specify the gSSURGO file geodatabase. The soil property or interpretation will summarized from this dataset and the summary table will be written to this gSSURGO database.

param.name: filters
param.dialogReference: There are hundreds of different soil properties and interpretations that can be summarized from a gSSURGO dataset. The "By Table" option allows you to browse specify any field an available SSURGO table. This option requires some understanding of the data structure. Soil Data Viewer Categories is a list of popular categories of data. Soil Data Viewer List is the complete list of popular soil properties and interpretations.

param.name: SDVcat1
param.dialogReference: Select a top level category of soil properties and interpretations. Once a category is selected you will be presented with a curated list soil properties and interpretations.

param.name: tables
param.expression: {Component | Horizon | Interpretations | Component Crop Yield: Irrigated | Component Crop Yield: Nonirrigated}
param.dialogReference:
Select a SSURGO table with the soil properties and interpretation you are looking for.

Component level tables contain information that describes the whole soil, such as drainage, taxonomy, site information, etc.

Horizon level tables contain information about the unique soil horizons, such as clay content, pH, etc.

Interpretations convey information about how suitable or limiting a soil type might be for certain activities or uses, such as buildings with basements or supporting Long Leaf Pines. These interpretations are pre-calculated at the component level but must be summarized to the map unit level.

param.name: attribute
param.dialogReference:
Specify a single soil property of interpretation to be summarized.

Note that you can search terms using the top drop down

param.name: primary
param.dialogReference:
This option is made available when summarizing Percent Present of nominal classes, such as Taxonomic Order, for example if you want to summarize how much of a map unit is of the soil order "Histisols".

It is also an option presented when selecting a crop when summarizing Component Crop Yield.

param.name: agmeth
param.dialogReference:
Aggregation Method is the process by which the soil property or interpretation is reduced to a single value that represents the map unit as a whole. A map unit is typically composed of one or more "components". A component is either some type of soil or some nonsoil entity, e.g., rock outcrop. For the attribute being aggregated, the first step of the aggregation process is to derive one attribute value for each of a map unit's components. From this set of component attributes, the next step of the aggregation process derives a single value that represents the map unit as a whole. Once a single value for each map unit is derived, a thematic map for soil map units can be rendered. Aggregation must be done because, on any soil map, map units are delineated but components are not. For each of a map unit's components, a corresponding percent composition is recorded. A percent composition of 60 indicates that the corresponding component typically makes up approximately 60% of the map unit. Percent composition is a critical factor in some, but not all, aggregation methods.

  • Dominant Condition: Available for categorical properties and interpretations. This aggregation method presents the most prevalent condition. It first groups components with the same class and sums the percent composition to determine the "dominant condition of a map unit. These groups now represent "conditions" rather than components. The attribute value associated with the group with the highest cumulative percent composition is returned. If more than one group shares the highest cumulative percent composition, the corresponding "tie-break" rule determines which value should be returned. The result returned by this aggregation method represents the dominant condition throughout the map unit only when no tie has occurred.

  • Dominant Component: Available for all properties and interpretations. This method returns the attribute value associated with the component with the highest percent composition in the map unit. The result returned by this aggregation method may or may not represent the dominant condition throughout the map unit. There is only one dominant component per map unit.

  • Weighted Average: Available for continuous soil properties and to acquire the weighted average of interpretation fuzzy values. Computes a weighted average value for all components in the map unit. Percent composition is the weighting factor. The result returned by this aggregation method represents a weighted average value of the corresponding attribute throughout the map unit.

  • Minimum: Available for continuous soil properties. The lowest attribute value among all components of the map unit. The result may correspond to a map unit component of very minor extent. This aggregation method is appropriate for either numeric attributes or attributes with a ranked or logically ordered domain.

  • Maximum: Available for continuous soil properties. The highest attribute value among all components of the map unit. The result may correspond to a map unit component of very minor extent. This aggregation method is appropriate for either numeric attributes or attributes with a ranked or logically ordered domain.

param.name: tie
param.dialogReference: The "tie-break" rule indicates whether the lower or higher group value should be returned in the case of a percent composition tie.

param.name: primaryNOT
param.displayname: Invert Primary Constraint to NOT equal

param.name: secondaryNOT
param.displayname: Invert Secondary Constraint to NOT equal

tool.summary:
The purpose of this tool is to aggregate soils information to the map unit level ( by mukey). Once soil information is aggregated to the map unit level it can be joined to MUPOLYGON and used to map the summarized property.

This tool is not compatible with SSURGO shapefiles because the associated attribute tables are in a different workspace.
